questions.question: A microoperation is an elementary operation performed during one clock pulse on the information stored in one or more registers.
Microoperations can include operations like shift, count, clear, load, and add.
A microoperation takes more than one clock cycle to complete.
Register Transfer Language (RTL) defines the set of registers and their functions.
The set of allowable microoperations is not provided by the organization of the computer.
Register transfer language is a symbolic language.
Register transfer language cannot be used to describe the internal organization of digital computers.
Register transfer language facilitates the design process of digital systems.
A sequence of microoperations is used to describe any function of the computer.
Register transfer language is not related to computer system architecture.
A register can be a portion of another register.
The transfer of bits from one register to another happens bit by bit over multiple clock pulses.
The condition 'p=1' determines when a transfer between registers occurs.
The numbering of bits in a register starts from 1.
A register can only be represented as a single block in diagrams.
Capital letters and numerals denote a register.
Parentheses ( ) denote a part of a register.
P: R2 ← R1 represents an unconditional transfer.
A block diagram is used to represent a register transfer.
A timing diagram is not used in register transfers.
Controlled transfers are represented using basic symbols.
The clock is not involved in register transfers.
MAR is an example of a register.
The arrow symbol denotes the transfer of information.
The comma symbol separates two micro-operations.
Data can move from register to register in digital logic.
Digital Logic Circuits are used for processing data.
C = A + B is an example of a digital logic operation.
Building a computer requires processing, storage, and communication components.
Mux 0 and Mux 1 are examples of multiplexers used in bus systems.
Bus 0 and Bus 1 are used for transferring data between registers.
S1 and S0 are control signals used in bus transfer operations.
A 4-line common bus is used for transferring data between registers in a 4-bit system.
Register D, Register C, Register B, and Register A are used in a 4-bit system.
The highest bit from each register is used for bus transfer operations.
The lowest bit from each register is used for bus transfer operations.
The number of multiplexers needed to construct the bus is equal to the number of bits in each register.
For register R0 to R63 in a 16-bit system, the MUX size used is 64X1.
For register R0 to R63 in a 16-bit system, 16 MUXs are needed.
For register R0 to R63 in a 16-bit system, 6 select bits are required.
A bus system can only be constructed with multiplexers, not with three-state gates.
A tri-state buffer can output 0, 1, or high-impedance (open circuit).
A buffer is used to match impedance between devices.
When the control input C=1 in a tri-state buffer gate, the output Y equals the input A.
When the control input C=0 in a tri-state buffer gate, the output Y equals the input A.
A tri-state buffer gate can output a high-impedance state.
The construction of a bus system does not involve tri-state buffers.
The transfer of information from a memory word to the outside environment is called memory transfer.
The transfer of new information to be stored into the memory is called a read operation.
In memory operations, DR stands for data register.
The operation 'DR  M[AR]' represents a write operation.
The operation 'M[AR]  R1' represents a write operation.
The operation 'AR  DR(AD)' transfers the content of the AD portion of register DR into register AR.
The operation 'A  constant' transfers a binary constant into register B.
R2 ← ABUS transfers the content of bus A into R2.
M[R] refers to the memory word specified by register R.
M is equivalent to M[DR].
DR ← M is a memory write operation.
M ← DR transfers the content of DR into the memory word specified by AR.
Multiplication and division are basic arithmetic operations.
A single circuit can perform both arithmetic addition and subtraction.
Register transfer microoperations are a type of microoperation.
Logic microoperations are not a type of microoperation.
Shift microoperations are a type of microoperation.
In the arithmetic addition operation R3 ← R1 + R2, the '+' symbol denotes logical OR.
Arithmetic subtraction can be represented as R3 ← R1 + R2 + 1 where R2 is the 1’s complement of R2.
Adding 1 to the one’s complement of R2 is equivalent to taking the 2’s complement of R2 and adding it to R1.
The addition and subtraction operations can be combined into one common circuit by including an XOR gate.
An XOR gate with each full-adder is used in binary adder-subtractor circuits.
When M=0 in a binary adder-subtractor, the operation is equivalent to a binary adder with carry in C0=1.
When M=1 in a binary adder-subtractor, the XOR gates output the 1's complement of B.
For unsigned numbers, when M=1, the operation A + B + 1 always results in A-B.
In a binary adder-subtractor, when M=1 and A<B, the result is the 2's complement of (B-A).
A 4-bit Binary Incrementer adds one to a number in a register.
A 4-bit Binary Incrementer can only be implemented as a sequential circuit.
A combinational circuit implementation of a 4-bit Binary Incrementer uses Half Adders.
The least significant Half Adder bit is connected to logic-0.
The output carry from one Half Adder is connected to the input of the next-higher-order Half Adder.
In a 4-bit Binary Incrementer, the value 1 is always added to the input.
The output of a 4-bit Binary Incrementer includes a carry bit labeled C4.
The outputs of a 4-bit Binary Incrementer are labeled S3, S2, S1, and S0.
A binary adder can perform subtraction operations.
The arithmetic microoperation D = A + Y + Cn is a standard addition operation.
A 4x1 MUX is used in the arithmetic circuit to select between different arithmetic operations.
The binary incrementer is not part of the arithmetic microoperations discussed.
The carry-out (Cout) in the binary adder is generated only when all inputs are 1.
The arithmetic circuit uses full adders (FA) to compute the results.
S0 and S1 are control signals that determine the operation performed by the arithmetic circuit.
The binary adder-subtractor cannot handle signed numbers.
The arithmetic microoperations include only addition and subtraction.
The inputs A0, B0, A1, B1, etc., are used to feed data into the arithmetic circuit.
In the given table, when S0 is 0 and Cin is 0, the microoperation is 'D = A + B'.
When S0 is 0 and Cin is 1, the microoperation is 'D = A + B + 1'.
When S0 is 1 and Cin is 0, the microoperation is 'D = A + B''.
When S0 is 1 and Cin is 1, the microoperation is 'D = A + B' + 1'.
When S0 is 1, Cin is 0, and the operation is 'D = A', it is a transfer operation.
When S0 is 1, Cin is 1, and the operation is 'D = A + 1', it is an increment operation.
When S0 is 1, Cin is 0, and the operation is 'D = A - 1', it is a decrement operation.
When S0 is 1, Cin is 1, and the operation is 'D = A', it is a transfer operation.
AND operation is useful for masking out certain groups of bits.
OR operation is used to merge binary or character data.
Logic microoperations involve manipulating bits stored in a register.
OR operation is useful for making logical decisions based on the bit value.
Different bitwise logical operations are selected by select signals in microoperations.
XNOR, NAND, NOR, and the complement of the second input cannot be accommodated in the extended logic circuit.
The output F0 is always 1 when X=0 and Y=0.
The truth table represents 16 functions of two variables.
The truth table is used to represent Boolean functions.
A multiplexer can select one of the 16 previous functions.
Logic operations can clear a group of bit values.
In the AND operation example, the result in R1 after applying the mask is 00000000 10101011.
In the SET operation example, the mask used is 11111111 00000000.
The INSERT operation involves masking the bits and then ORing them with the required value.
In the AND operation example, the mask used is 00000000 11111111.
In the SET operation example, the result in R1 after applying the mask is 11111111 10101011.
The INSERT operation does not involve masking the bits before ORing them with the required value.
In the OR operation example, the result of A before OR B mask is 0000 1010.
The complement operation is performed using the XOR operation with a mask of ones.
In the shift microoperations example, the binary number 11000 is shifted to the left by one position.
The result of the OR operation between A before (0110 1010) and B mask (0000 1111) is 0000 1010.
The complement operation example shows that XORing 10101101 10101011 with 11111111 00000000 results in 01010010 10101011.
Shift microoperations are used for serial transfer of data.
There are four types of shift microoperations.
Logical, Circular, and Arithmetic are types of shift microoperations.
R ← shl R represents a shift-right operation.
R ← cil R represents a circular shift-left operation.
A logical shift transfers 1 through the serial input.
The bit transferred to the end position through the serial input is assumed to be 0 during a logical shift.
Arithmetic shift-left operation is represented as R ← ashl R.
Arithmetic shift-right operation is represented as R ← ashr R.
A logical shift-right operation on the binary number 10100011 results in 01000110.
A circular shift-left operation on the binary number 10100011 results in 01000111.
An arithmetic shift-left operation multiplies a signed binary number by 2.
A circular shift operation loses information from the register.
An arithmetic shift-right operation divides a signed binary number by 2.
In arithmetic shifts, the sign bit does not receive any special treatment.
In an arithmetic right-shift, Rn-1 remains unchanged.
For a negative number, 0 is shifted from the sign bit to the right.
A negative number is represented by the 2’s complement.
In Example 1, 0100 (4) shifted right becomes 0010 (2).
In Example 2, 1010 (-6) shifted right becomes 1101.
The operation of Arithmetic Shift Left is the same as Logic Shift Left.
In Arithmetic Shift Left, you need to check for overflow problems.
Arithmetic Shift Left inserts a 1 in the LSB.
In Example 1, Arithmetic Shift Left of 0010 (2) results in 0100 (4).
In Example 2, Arithmetic Shift Left of 1110 (-2) results in 1100 (-4).
In Example 3, Arithmetic Shift Left of 0100 (4) results in 1000 (overflow).
In Example 4, Arithmetic Shift Left of 1010 (-6) results in 0100 (overflow).
